summary: This is a New York Times article reporting on Jeffrey Epstein's death by suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan on August 10, 2019. It details the circumstances of his death, the ongoing investigations, and provides background on his crimes, wealth, and high-profile connections.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the article; found dead by suicide in his jail cell while awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges.

persons.name: William K. Rashbaum
persons.context: Co-author of the article, a senior writer covering corruption and law enforcement.

persons.name: Benjamin Weiser
persons.context: Co-author of the article, a reporter covering Manhattan federal courts.

persons.name: William P. Barr
persons.role: Attorney General of the United States
persons.context: Issued a statement expressing being appalled by Epstein's death and announcing an FBI investigation and an Inspector General inquiry.

persons.name: Reid Weingarten
persons.context: Part of Epstein's defense team; declined to comment on his cause of death.

persons.name: Marty Weinberg
persons.context: Part of Epstein's defense team; declined to comment on his cause of death.

persons.name: Michael Miller
persons.context: Part of Epstein's defense team; declined to comment on his cause of death.

persons.name: Donald J. Trump
persons.context: Mentioned as one of the high-profile individuals Epstein had associated with over the years.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Mentioned as one of the high-profile individuals Epstein had associated with over the years.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned as one of the high-profile individuals Epstein had associated with over the years.

persons.name: Leslie H. Wexner
persons.role: Retail billionaire, founder of L Brands
persons.context: Described as Epstein's most notable client and the source of much of his wealth; accused Epstein of misappropriating vast sums from him.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Described in a court memo as Jeffrey Epstein's only living immediate family member and that they were close.

persons.name: Leon Black
persons.context: Mentioned as a Wall Street titan who faced questions about socializing with Epstein after his 2008 conviction.

persons.name: Jes Staley
persons.context: Mentioned as a Wall Street titan who faced questions about socializing with Epstein after his 2008 conviction.

connections.description: Wexner was Epstein's biggest client, giving him vast authority to manage his personal fortune for 16 years, which was the primary source of Epstein's wealth.
Mark is Jeffrey's younger brother and his only living immediate family member; described as close in a court memo.
Weingarten was part of Epstein's defense team for his federal sex trafficking case.
Weinberg was part of Epstein's defense team for his federal sex trafficking case.
Miller was part of Epstein's defense team for his federal sex trafficking case.
Trump is listed among the high-profile individuals Epstein had associated with over the years.
Clinton is listed among the high-profile individuals Epstein had associated with over the years.
Prince Andrew is listed among the high-profile individuals Epstein had associated with over the years.
Black was a Wall Street contact who socialized with Epstein even after his 2008 conviction.
Staley was a Wall Street contact who socialized with Epstein even after his 2008 conviction.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead by hanging in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan at roughly 6:30 a.m.

events.title: Previous Suicide Attempt/Incident
events.description: Epstein was found unconscious in his cell with marks on his neck, investigated as a possible suicide attempt. He was placed on suicide watch afterward.

events.title: Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was removed from suicide watch and returned to the special housing unit at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Arrest at Teterboro Airport
events.description: Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey after his private plane landed from Paris on federal sex trafficking charges.

events.title: Florida Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein avoided federal charges by pleading guilty to state charges of solicitation of prostitution from a minor, serving 13 months in jail with work release privileges.

events.title: Release of Sealed Documents
events.description: A federal appeals court released a cache of previously sealed legal documents providing new details about activities inside Epstein's homes and recruitment of victims.

locations: Private island, United States Virgin Islands
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide via hanging in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan on the morning of August 10, 2019.
Epstein had been removed from suicide watch on July 29, 2019, after a previous incident on July 23 where he was found with marks on his neck.
Attorney General William Barr ordered an FBI investigation and an Inspector General inquiry into the circumstances of Epstein's death.
Much of Epstein's wealth was attributed to his management of Leslie Wexner's personal fortune, and Wexner later accused him of misappropriating 'vast sums of money'.
Epstein's death occurred while he was awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges for which he faced up to 45 years in prison.
